nodes.text: PCA-based dimensionality reduction can improve machine learning performance and computational efficiency for hyperspectral optical imaging regression tasks such as soil moisture estimation
Hyperspectral optical imaging datasets exhibit high dimensionality, strong band-to-band correlations, and redundancy that challenge machine learning models
The study uses a hyperspectral dataset of 679 samples with 125 spectral bands (450-950 nm) and soil moisture reference values measured by TDR sensor
Data preprocessing: spectral features standardized with StandardScaler, fixed random state 42, train-test split with test size 0.3 for reproducibility

PCA applied via sklearn.decomposition.PCA after standardization; component selection criterion: retain more than 99 percent cumulative variance, validated by covariance matrix, eigenvalue distribution and scree plot
Explained variance ratios for principal components: PC1 = 0.9889, PC2 = 0.0064, PC3 = 0.0023, PC4 = 0.0016 (cumulative: PC1=0.9889, PC1+PC2=0.9953)
Retaining only the first two principal components preserves over 99 percent of total variance in the dataset
Projection onto PC1 and PC2 provides improved visualization and clearer separation of samples by soil moisture compared to higher-dimensional spectral space
PC1 vs PC2 projection with soil moisture color mapping shows clustering trend and separation according to normalized soil moisture
A Random Forest Regressor (n_estimators=100, random_state=42) was trained on the PCA-transformed features and evaluated using R2 on the test set
The Random Forest model trained on PCA-transformed data achieved coefficient of determination R2 = 0.947 (94.7 percent)
PCA-based dimensionality reduction preserves strong predictive capability while reducing data complexity and improving computational efficiency for soil moisture regression on this dataset
Conclusion: PCA is an effective baseline dimensionality reduction strategy for hyperspectral regression tasks, enabling interpretable, scalable workflows without compromising accuracy

Limitation and future work: results are demonstrated on a single field campaign dataset and a linear dimensionality reduction method; alternative feature extraction methods and testing across diverse imaging scenarios and sensors are recommended
Correlation analysis and heatmap of selected bands reveal strong interband correlations (e.g., around 642 nm and 742 nm), indicating spectral redundancy amenable to dimensionality reduction
